reporting-org.narrative: Environmental Centre for Oil Spills and Gas Flaring (NACGOND)

title.narrative:
2.1 Round tables for Policy briefings (Civil Society, State and Local governments, academia and community groups).
2.2 Lobbying and advocacy visits to The Ministry of Environment and The National Assembly.
2.3 Sensitization of communities to stop pipeline vandalism and artisanal refining of crude oil.
2.4 Sustained media advocacy on long term sustainable alternatives to oil theft and artisanal refining in the Niger Delta.

description.narrative: Initiate a dialogue and sensitization between oil producing communities, civil society groups, oil majors and the Nigerian government for workable long term sustainable alternatives to oil theft and artisanal refining.

participating-org.narrative: Centre for Environment, Human Rght and Development
Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP)

activity-date.narrative: This activity was implemented for 5 and half years in all between October, 2016 - April, 2021 in multiple locations within Nigeria.

organisation.narrative: National Coordinator, Environmental Centre for Oil Spills and Gas Flaring (NACGOND)

mailing-address.narrative: #17 Ndashi street, D/Line, Port Harcourt, Rivers State, Nigeria.

recipient-country.narrative: Activity started in 2016 and lasted till 2021 with 4 policy dialogues held in two states to brainstorm on long term sustainable alternatives to oil theft and artisanal refining activities which has impacted negatively on the environment and traditional forms of livelihood across project communities in the Niger Delta region of Nigeria.

sector.narrative: Policy dialogues were used to develop documents for engagement with state actors for national and state policy and legislative actions aimed at engaging the youths in sustainable livelihood options with long term results being improved environmental performance and livelihood security in project communities.

provider-org.narrative: Project activities were funded by the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Nigeria.

receiver-org.ref: Environmental Centre for Oil Spills and Gas Flaring (NACGOND)
receiver-org.narrative: NACGOND is a coalition of 26 NGOs, CSOs and Academia based in the Sotuh-South region of Nigeria.

title.narrative: Video evidence with beneficiaries acknowledging programme benefits throughout the entire project life cycle.

description.narrative: The Niger-Delta region where this intervention was implemented required protection from continued environmental degradation that affects the environment and traditional forms of livelihoods. Actions of stakeholders needed to be coordinated to ensure that laws, bills and policies such as Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) are reviewed and implemented to put an end to oil pollution, gas flaring and other forms of degradation in a speedy way in order to protect the citizenry from pollution and give them a sense of belonging which was lacking.

title.narrative: Number of youths that embrace other income generation sources.

description.narrative: Number of school age youths involved in oil theft, pipeline vandalism of crude, artisanal refining and unsustainable logging activities was significantly higher prior to intervention period. This was impacting heavily on the environment and traditional forms of livelihood in communities that the project was implemented.

baseline.value: 80% of youths involved in oil theft and artisanal refining related activities do not have any other source of income.

location.ref: Parts of Cross River, Akwa Ibom, Rivers, Abia, Bayelsa and Delta States in South-South Nigeria

dimension.name: Actions of youths in project communities causing oil spills through third party interference are curtailed in such a way that environmental standards in the Niger Delta improve with youths embracing other income generating sources.
dimension.value: Youths of secondary school age (both boys and girls)

comment.narrative: Continued environmental degradation affected the environment and traditional forms of livelihoods so actions of stakeholders was needed to be coordinated to ensure that laws, bills and policies such as Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) were reviewed and implemented to put an end to oil pollution, gas flaring and other forms of degradation in a speedy way in project communities.

target.value: About 40% reduction in frequency of reported oil theft and artisanal refining incidences in project communities between 2017 and 2019 with resurgence of incidence in 2020. However, only 30% of the youths who stopped these acts in project communities do have alternative livelihood sources to rely on. More than 60% of dwellers in project communities have planted trees for environmental protection.

actual.value: More than 75% but less than 78% of youths involved in oil theft in target communities still does not have any other source of income.

location.ref: 6 project states in the Niger Delta region of Nigeria.
